thread.title_full: Julianne Moore stands out in four-hankie, fact-based ‘Freeheld’ | Boston Herald

author: Stephen Schaefer
title: Julianne Moore stands out in four-hankie, fact-based ‘Freeheld’
text:
We know how astonishing Julianne Moore can be as she battles disease (last year’s Oscar for “Still Alice”), prejudice (“Far From Heaven”) or portrays a real-life person (Sarah Palin in “Game Change”).
In the four-hankie “Freeheld,” Moore memorably does all three.
She’s heartbreaking as real-life decorated New Jersey detective Laurel Hester, a closeted lesbian with terminal lung cancer who wants her earned pension benefits to go to her live-in lover Stacie Andree (Ellen Page).
It is 2006 and the women have, under New Jersey law, a domestic partnership. Same-sex marriage wasn’t yet legal.
So Laurel’s request is put before the Ocean County, N.J., officials, the all-male Freeholders (who include Josh Charles of “The Good Wife”) and is summarily rejected.
A political battle, one that despite its seriousness has many comical overtones, erupts.
Laurel’s partner, detective Dane Wells (an excellent Michael Shannon), is initially flabbergasted that she’s a lesbian and hurt that she hadn’t confided in him.
But as the going gets rough, Wells steps up as her biggest supporter in a police department that seems shamefully reluctant to support one of its own and includes a closeted homosexual and a loudmouth bigot.
After local news broadcasts the women’s plight, the story quickly expands nationwide, led by the self-described Jewish gay activist Steven Goldstein (a very funny, very broad Steve Carell), who likes nothing more than unloading a bus of demonstrators to disrupt these once-staid Freeholders hearings.
Director Peter Sollett wisely keeps the focus on the two very private women at the center of a storm that never should have broken.
Nine months after Laurel’s death, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled same-sex couples have the same rights as heterosexual ones.
The film is adapted from Laurel and Stacie’s story as told in Cynthia Wade’s “Freeheld,” which won an Academy Award as best documentary short subject in 2008.
This dramatization, scripted by “Philadelphia” scribe Ron Nyswaner, is especially thanks to Moore, a worthy coda.
(“Freeheld” has an adult relationship and issues as well as language.)
